TEXT:
Admission Date:  [**2151-7-24**]     Discharge Date:  [**2151-8-2**]

Date of Birth:   [**2133-4-7**]     Sex:  M

Service:  MICU

CHIEF COMPLAINT:  Gram-negative sepsis.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is an 18-year-old
male with no significant past medical history aside from an
"innocent" heart murmur diagnosed as a child.  He was in his
usual state of health until six days prior to admission when
he began experiencing a sore throat.

Three days prior to admission, he began experiencing fever,
chills, malaise, sweats, and right sided chest pain.  Twelve
days prior to admission, the patient had been to the dentist
and had work done on his teeth.  The patient went to his PCP
three days prior to admission and was diagnosed with
mononucleosis.  At that time he had a white blood cell count
of 26.  The patient continued to feel poorly with shortness
of breath, chest pain, cough, and fever.

Two days prior to admission, the patient presented to [**Hospital1 51631**] Hospital, where a chest x-ray showed a possible
pneumonia.  The patient was started on azithromycin and
ceftriaxone.  He was noted to have a fever of 103.  He was
admitted to [**Hospital 1562**] Hospital, where a followup chest CT scan
showed septic emboli bilaterally.  Followup blood cultures
grew 4/4 bottles of gram-positive cocci identified as group-C
Strep and one bottle grew gram-negative rods consistent with
fusobacterium.  The patient was given Vancomycin, Zosyn, and
clindamycin.  The patient continued to be dyspneic, and was
transferred from [**Hospital 1562**] Hospital to the [**Hospital1 346**] Emergency Department at 2 am on [**7-24**].

On arrival in the Emergency Department, the patient's
temperature was 99.8, his blood pressure was 112/45, heart
rate 133, respiratory rate was 30, and he was sating 96% on
room air.  In the Emergency Department, he was put on 6
liters of oxygen and then continued to [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] was put on
100% nonrebreather mask.  His arterial blood gas showed a pH
of 7.33, a pCO2 of 52, a pAO2 of 210.  Chest x-ray showed
bilateral effusions with right greater than left and a
density of the right lung base.

Echocardiogram was done for the concern of possible septic
endocarditis which showed a thickened pulmonic valve and a
possible vegetation.  No PDA.  Left ventricular function was
globally depressed with the left ventricular ejection
fraction of 45-50%.  The patient underwent thoracentesis in
the Emergency Room and pleural fluid showed a severe
parapneumonic effusion with a pH of 7.17, white blood cell
count of 2,350, a LDH of 2,860.

The patient's breathing remained labored in the Emergency
Room and the decision was made to intubate the patient.
Followup chest CT scan showed a possible right upper lobe
pleural based opacity consistent with a septic embolus in the
lung.  Blood cultures from [**Hospital1 1562**] revealed gram-negative
rods anaerobic bottle thought to be fusobacterium.

Leg pain and swelling along with the fusobacterium raise
concern for internal jugular thrombus leading to a neck
ultrasound in the Medical Intensive Care Unit, which revealed
a left internal jugular clot of 1.5 cm.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Murmur noted in childhood thought to
be an innocent murmur.

ALLERGIES:  Sulfa with an unknown reaction.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  The patient lives in [**Location (un) 3844**] with his
parents.  He is a recent high school graduate.  He reports
two sexual partners with protection and denies IV drug use.
Denies tobacco.  Admits to occasional alcohol use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  On physical exam on admission, the
patient's temperature was 101.8, heart rate was 122, blood
pressure 110/39.  His respiratory rate was 22, and his oxygen
saturation was 100% on ventilatory support.  In general, the
patient was an ill appearing young male lying in bed,
intubated, and lightly sedated on propofol.  On head, eyes,
ears, nose, and throat examination, his pupils are equal,
round, and reactive to light and accommodation.  His sclerae
were anicteric.  Oropharynx are dry with no exudates.  Neck
was supple with tenderness to palpation noted on the left
side greater than the right side and tenderness to rotation
on the left with left anterior cervical adenopathy.  The left
side of the neck was erythematous and warm to touch.  Chest
examination revealed bronchial breath sounds and dullness
half way up on the right side and dullness to the left base
with crackles a third of the way up on the left.  Abdominal
examination was soft, nontender, nondistended abdomen with
positive bowel sounds.  Extremities examination showed no
clubbing, cyanosis, or edema.  No Osler's, [**Last Name (un) 1003**], or
splinter hemorrhages.  Skin examination revealed linear
erythematous papular rash on the trunk at the level of T12 in
a dermatomal pattern.

LABORATORIES AT OUTSIDE HOSPITAL:  Laboratories in the
Emergency Department revealed a sodium of 132, potassium 4.2,
a chloride of 98, bicarb of 23, BUN of 28, and creatinine of
1.0, glucose of 92, ALT is 30, AST of 57, alkaline
phosphatase of 89, total bilirubin 0.9, amylase of 42, a CPK
of 238 with a MB fraction of 3, and a troponin of less than
0.3.  PT of 12.5, PTT of 29.3.  White count was 19.9,
hematocrit was 39, and platelets were 104.

Chest CT scan on admission revealed bilateral pleural
effusions right greater than left with fluid tracking to the
major fissure on the right.  In addition, a right upper lobe
peripherally based patchy opacity.  Small focus patchy
opacities were scattered throughout both lungs.  There was no
consolidation noted at the bases.

A CT scan of the abdomen was read as within normal limits.  A
CT scan of the pelvis was read as within normal limits.  A CT
scan of the head revealed no hemorrhage, no mass effect or
shift and clear paranasal sinuses.  The bone windows on the
CT scan of the pelvis were read as no lytic or blastic
lesions noted.

A neck ultrasound revealed partially occluded thrombus in the
left internal jugular vein with flow around the thrombus.

ASSESSMENT:  The patient is an 18-year-old male with some
history what he felt previously to be an innocent heart
murmur.  He presented 12 days after a dental cleaning with
fevers, cough, positive blood cultures, and a bedside
echocardiogram suspicious for a pulmonic thrombic lesion.
Considered was endocarditis with septic emboli to the lungs,
however, a neck ultrasound revealed a left internal jugular
clot and this was thought to be the source of septic emboli.

Thus, the patient was given the diagnosis of Lemierre's
syndrome.

PROBLEM LIST BY SYSTEM:
1. Lemierre's with septic pulmonary emboli (septic
thrombophlebitis of internal jugular vein).  Infectious
Disease was immediately consulted and recommended treatment
with ceftriaxone, Flagyl, and gentamicin to cover group C
Streptococcus and anaerobic gram-negative rods.  A head,
chest, pelvis, abdomen CT scan was done to evaluate for a
possible further emboli.  The CT scan showed no lesions in
the head, abdomen, or pelvis with multiple nodules in the
lungs consistent with septic emboli and decreased signal in
the left internal jugular vein.

Ultrasound of the neck showed a 1.5 mm clot in the left
internal jugular vein.  Xigris was considered for sepsis, but
the patient did not meet the criteria as he is not in shock,
and there was concern for anticoagulation with his bloody
thoracentesis fluid.

Cultures were requested from [**Hospital 1562**] Hospital.
Otolaryngology was consulted to evaluate for possible
internal jugular vein ligation.  They recommended
Heparinization to prevent propagation of the clot and
mentioned that surgery was not indicated unless the clot
progressed after 24 hours of antibiotics.  Therefore, a
repeat ultrasound was planned for 24 hours.

The patient remained febrile overnight with a maximum
temperature of 105.0 and a steady temperature of 102.4.  The
patient received a cooling blanket.

A morning chest x-ray was more worrisome for increased
pulmonary emboli and increased pleural effusions.  Infectious
Disease recommended starting acyclovir at 900 mg IV for a
possible herpetic rash.  The following day, ultrasound showed
extension of the clot past the mandible.  The proximal
thrombosis was not visualized with decreased flow noted in
the internal jugular vein with near total occlusion.
Otolaryngology felt that internal jugular ligation was not
warranted at that time.  They recommended ordering a
transesophageal echocardiogram and a MRV/MRA to evaluate for
excessive fluid collection and documentation of further
pulmonary events.

The transesophageal echocardiogram showed no signs of
vegetation on any of the valves of the heart.  MRV/MRA of the
chest and neck showed left lower lobe collapse, smaller
embolic events on the left.

Since the patient was not improving, his antibiotic coverage
was changed to penicillin, gentamicin, and Flagyl.  When the
gram-negative rods was identified at [**Hospital 1562**] Hospital as
Porphyromonas asatchrolytica (bacteroides species) on
[**2151-7-26**] for increased efficacy.

Otolaryngology was being consulted in light of the poor CT
scan of the chest and worry of continuous septic emboli.
They recommended that surgery would not improve clinical
outcome.  Heparin was started and initially discontinued for
seizure-like activity. A followup CT scan of the head was
negative for bleed.

A MRV in diffusion lighted scan was read as extensive
internal jugular vein involvement and possible cavernous
sinus clot.  Heparin was restarted due to proposition of the
thrombus.

Neurosurgery consult was obtained and also supported in
anticoagulated the patient.  Infectious Disease recommended
stopping penicillin and clindamycin as they were seizuregenic
and restarting ceftriaxone and Vancomycin.

On [**2151-7-25**], Vancomycin was discontinued since the patient
had no signs of MRSA.  On [**2151-7-27**], ceftriaxone was changed
to penicillin 4 mg IV q4 as no seizures were noted on
followup electroencephalogram and these drugs were felt to be
the ideal drugs for the organism.

A CT scan of the neck was obtained with contrast to evaluate
for a drainable absence, no fluid collection was seen,
however, stranding in the subcutaneous fascia and thickened
cervical fascia was seen.  A repeat neck CT scan on [**7-30**] to
assess for clot progression or abscess formation showed no
progression of the clot and no abscess collection.
Therefore, the patient was continued on penicillin,
gentamicin, and metronidazole.  He was also continued on
Heparin with a goal of a PTT from 50-80.

Infectious Disease recommended a repeat MRV as well as a
repeat neck ultrasound before discharge and follow up with
Infectious Disease upon discharge.

2. Pulmonary effusions/emboli:  Thoracentesis on admission
showed a complicated pleural effusion.  Thoracic Surgery was
consulted, and placed a right chest tube which drained 310 cc
of serosanguinous fluid immediately, and 600 cc of fluid
overall.  A left chest tube was placed on [**2151-7-26**] with
drainage of 700 cc overall and expansion of the collapsed
left lower lung.  The right lower lung continued to remain
atelectatic with no further drainage.

Therefore, a repeat chest CT scan on [**2151-7-28**] was done to
evaluate the effusion, and the possibility of placing a
second right sided chest tube.  This CT scan showed a right
upper lobe embolus with cavitation and a mid sized right
effusion, large area with right lower lobe atelectasis and a
right lower lobe effusion.  CT Surgery felt that the chest
tube was in the correct place and that no further chest tubes
were warranted.

Bronchoscopy was therefore performed because of persistent
fevers and a high white count that revealed thick upper
airway secretions, but no bronchiolar plugs.  Bronchial
lavage was sent which did not reveal any organisms on Gram
stain and did not grow out any organisms.

On [**2151-8-2**], the patient's right chest tube was removed as it
had drained less than 100 cc in the last 24 hours.

3. Dermatology:  The patient was noted to have a linear
erythematous rash on his trunk in T12 dermatomal
distribution.  He was briefly on acyclovir, but a followup
HSV was negative for varicella zoster virus.

The next day vesicular erythematous lesion was also noted on
the patient's right medial shin.  There was concern for toxic
shock syndrome with the picture of fevers and rash.
Dermatology was consulted to swab these lesions.  Preliminary
cultures did not grow any herpes zoster virus, so acyclovir
was discontinued on [**2151-7-28**].  The rash on the trunk was
treated with cortisone cream per Dermatology recommendations
and was resolving on transfer to the floor.

4. Cardiac:  A transesophageal echocardiogram was done on
[**2151-7-26**] and showed no vegetations.  The patient was
maintained on Telemetry while in the MICU, and no conduction
abnormalities or electrocardiogram abnormalities were noted.

5. Neurology:  The patient was noted to have seizure-like
activity after his Heparin bolus on [**2151-7-25**].  The patient
developed fine tremors, upper extremity posturing, and
downward gaze.  A seizure evaluation by Neurology consult
recommended Dilantin loading.  The patient became hypotensive
with Dilantin and was therefore switched to fosphenytoin.  A
subsequent electroencephalogram was negative, and Neurology
recommended continuing Dilantin prophylactically and
re-evaluating when off sedation.  An anticoagulation panel
was sent and was still pending at time of transfer to the
floor.

The patient's Dilantin was discontinued on [**2151-8-2**] after
evaluation by Neurology, while the patient was awake, alert.
Electroencephalogram was repeated at this time and was
negative.

6. Pulmonary:  Patient was intubated for hypoxia and
hypercapnic respiratory failure.  The patient did well on
ventilation settings of assist control 450, 520 with 40%
FIO2.  Compliance was calculated at 26 and was thought to be
a combination of suppination, pleural effusions, septic
emboli, and fluid overload.

On [**2151-7-28**], the patient's sedation was lightened so he can
be tried on pressure support of 20 and PEEP of 5.  The
patient did well from 6 am to 4 pm, and then self extubated.
The patient was placed on 100% nonrebreather mask with oxygen
saturations from 98-100%.  Initially, the respiratory rate
was 20-40.  The patient was given Fentanyl for pain control
and improved. The patient was switched to Dilaudid for better
pain control and did well subsequently on 5 liters nasal
cannula.

7. Renal:  The patient maintained good renal function
throughout his hospital stay with no change in creatinine and
no decrease in urine output.  The patient's renal function
was monitored closely given his CT dye load, gentamicin,
Vancomycin, and acyclovir.  He was given nitrite boluses and
................

8. The patient received prophylactic proton-pump inhibitor on
Heparin during his MICU stay.

9. Pain control:  After the patient extubated and woke up,
pain control became an issue.  The patient was initially
started on Fentanyl, but due to decreased pain control and
increased nausea, he was switched to Dilaudid.  The patient
did better on Dilaudid PCA with decreased nausea and much
better pain control.

The patient was discharged to the floor on [**2151-8-2**].

Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF HOSPITAL COURSE:  Ms. [**Known lastname 6129**] is a 77yo female with PMH as
listed above who presented with hypotension.  She was treated
broadly initially for sepsis, and it was determined that the
likely source was C.difficile colitis.  Her toxin B was
eventually positive.  She had respiratory failure in the setting
of septic shock.  She had persistent hypotension while
intubated, and required vasopressors.  She completed a two week
course of antibiotics for her c.dif colitis.

She developed diffuse anasarca from volume resuscitation.  It
became difficult to mobilize her fluids because she was felt to
be intravascularly dry.  Eventually, a lasix drip was started,
and she was successfully extubated.

She was also noted to be severely hypothyroid (her replacement
medications had been stopped for some reason prior to
admission).  She was started on IV synthroid after consultation
with endocrinology.

In addition to her fluid overload state, she was very weak.  She
was receiving enteral nutrition during most of her stay, but
remained very weak.

She also had a pleural effusion that was tapped and was
transudative after analysis.  It was felt to be due to volume
resucitiation and diastolic heart failure.  The fluid
reaccumulated.

She also developed a GI bleed, which was felt to be due to an
upper source, and GI was consulted.  They recommended supportive
care, and that an urgent endoscopy / colonoscopy would not alter
her course.

Once she was extubated, she had an acute event of possible
aspiration vs. flash pulmonary edema that lead to her being
re-intubated.  She had difficulty weaning off of the ventilator
due to profound weakness and volume overload.

Then, she developed a tachyarrhythmia - atrial fibrillation and
atrial flutter.  Her BP was very sensitive to this rhythm, and
she required DC cardioversion.  She was loaded on amiodarone and
esmolol, and she once again developed this tachy rhythm.  Given
that she had then completed an IV load of amiodarone, DC
cardioversion was done again, and she returned to sinus
bradycardia with a good BP.

Given that her heart had become somewhat unstable, and there was
very little progress in weaning her from the ventilator, family
discussions were held regularly to discuss goals of care.  Then,
at a meeting one day prior to her death, the decision was made
by her daughter and HCP, as well as her husband, to gather
family and to terminally extubate her.  This was done on 6/ 27/
08 at 6pm, and she expired with her entire family at her bedside
very peacefully by 6:20pm.

She remained on DVT prophylaxis during the stay.  Other issues,
such as pain control for her hip fracture, were adequately
addressed.  She was given insulin, bronchodilators, mouth care,
pressure ulcer prophylaxis.

Upon transfer to the Hepatorenal service, the patient was alert,

consistently excellent oxygen saturation. Diagnostic

status on the evening of [**10-12**]. She had an ABG performed, and
subsequently developed a hematoma. Her hand was felt to be cold

.

to metabolic insult, and has had wide fluctuations in his mental

voiding trial with PVR 700 [**2133-5-22**], and underwent TID straight

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hepatobiliary service on
[**2106-12-11**].  His encephalopathy was thought to be baseline as well
as due to dehydration.  A RUQ ultrasound revealed no portal vein
thrombosis.  He was afebrile with a normal WBC, but was
pan-cultured anyway.  UA was negative.  Hematocrit was stable at
30.  Ceftriaxone was started empirically for possible peritoneal
infection. Lactulose was continued.  He was aggressively
hydrated.  He also had a createnine of 2.1 (baseline 1.5) and a
sodium of 124 (baseline 132).  His FeNa was < 1%, so this was
likely pre-renal.  He could not have a feeding tube placed due
to recent bleeding, and required supervised oral feeding.  His
MELD on admission was 31.  Ceftriaxone was discontined HD 2 (no
signs of infection).  Lactulose was titrated so as to get [**4-9**]
BMs daily.  On HD 2, createnine was down to 1.6.  Physical
therapy saw him and felt he should progress to be discharged
home.  On HD 5, he became lightheaded and dropped to his feet
while walking.  Denied loss of consciousness.  Thought to be due
to orthostasis.  His BP was 60/palp and HR was 110.  He was
helped back to bed and his HR and BP returned to [**Location 213**] (SBP
100, HR 90).  His CMV viral load was negative.  His Hct was 22,
so he was transfused 2 units RBCs for [**Location **] loss anemia.  His
INR was 3.0, so he was transfused 3 units of FFP to correct his
coagulopathy.  A CT scan revealed a right-side retroperitoneal
hematoma.  At that time, he was transferred to the trnasplant
surgery serivce and sent to the ICU.

On HD 6, the patient was intubated.  A central venous catheter
and arterial line were placed.  From this point on, this patient
required aggressive transfusion of RBCs, FFP, platelets and
Cryo.  Over the night, his Hct dropped to 15, then rose to 18,
then 25, then 27. His platelets went fro 50 to 29 to 91 to 153.
His INR went from 3.3 to 2.8 to 2.5 to 0.6.  He required 11
units of RBCs, 2 of platelets, 4 of FFP, 1 of cryo and 1 of
factor 7.  On HD 7, his Hct dropped from 28 to 11 over 3 hours.
He did not have guiac + stools and hig NG tube outpuit was
[**Last Name (LF) 63675**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] his [**First Name3 (LF) **] loss anemia was though to be entirely
due to his retroperiotneal hematoma.  TIPS and surgery were
considered, but the mortality was thought to be too high.  Over
the day, he reuired 9 units of RBCs, 2 platelets, 4 FFP, 2 cryo
and 1 of factor 7.  A dialysis catheter was placed for CVVHD.
Vancomycin, levofloxacin, and fluconazole were begun
empirically.  The goal was to transfuse [**First Name3 (LF) **] products to keep
Hct > 27, Plt > 75, and INR < 2.0.  He required maximum pressor
support (neosynepherine, vasopressin and levophed).  Despite
extremes in transfusion of [**First Name3 (LF) **] products, we were not able to
stop his bleeding.  A family meeting was arranged and the
decision was made to hold all pressor support and [**First Name3 (LF) **]

Brief Hospital Course:
79 year-old Male with a PMH significant for coronary artery
disease (s/p CABG [**35**] years prior), prior MI, hypertension who
presented to an outside hospital with chest pain who underwent
PCI who was intubated for respiratory failure in the cardiac
catheterization lab and who required placement of an
intra-aortic balloon pump for cardiogenic shock and subsequently
expired due to ventricular tachycardia.
.
# CARDIOGENIC SHOCK - The patient presents with a known history
of ischemic cardiomyopathy, with recent EF of 35-40%. During his
left heart catheterization procedure this admission, the patient
began to experience acute respiratory failure, likely secondary
to worsening cardiogenic shock. The etiology of his cardiogenic
shock was likely secondary to a cathecholamine surge which
occurred during the catheterization procedure, as he was laid
supine. There was also a component of  anxiety associated with
the procedure. His right heart catheterization revealed a PCWP
of 31 mmHg, which was improved with the placement of an
intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) to 18 mmHg. The IABP was
maintained in good position and was assisting ventricular
contraction initially at a 1:1 ratio which supported his mean
arterial pressures to an average of 55-60 mmHg. He was slowly
weaned to a 2:1 ratio over the course of 48-hours with
subsequent removal of the IABP 3-days into admission. A
Norepinphrine gtt was utilized to support his systolic pressures
and peripheral vasculature while the balloon pump was being
utilized. His systolic pressures actually remained elevated
following the removal of the device and he requried transient
use of a Nitroglycerin gtt to control his systolic pressures.
While the IABP was in place, his distal pulses were closely
monitored and daily CXRs showed adequate balloon positioning.
His platelets and hematocrit were also closely monitoring, with
a drop in his platelets from 257 to 125 this admission. He
showed no evidence of bleeding nonetheless. We added back his
home anti-hypertensives once his blood pressure stabilized and
his cardiac function improved. His digoxin level remained
therapeutic this admission. He was also treated with IV Lasix as
needed, to promote diuresis.
.
# RESPIRATORY FAILURE AND HYPOXIA - The patient required urgent
intubation in the cardiac catheterization lab likely secondary
to pulmonary edema in the setting of his cardiogenic shock. He
received Lasix and Nitroglycerin in the cath lab, and once his
IABP was removed and diuresis was employed, he was successfully
extubated without issues. He transiently required Fentanyl and
Versed gtts to maintain sedation while intubated. Following
extubation, the patient was delirious. He had another episode of
flash pulmonary edema which was responsive to lasix,
nitroglycerin drip, morphine.
.
# CORONARIES - The patient presented with known coronary disease
involving 3-vessels. The patient was found to have a 90%
stenotic lesion of the left main coronary artery, which
underwent drug-eluting stent placement. He also has a known
history of prior CABG. Prior to his cardiac intervention, given
his chest pain, he was started on heparin gtt and maintained on
Aspirin therapy. Integrillin was added given continued chest
pain. His statin medication was optimized to high dose
Atorvastatin 80 mg PO daily. He was also Plavix loaded with 600
mg PO x 1 prior to his catheterization. Following his
catheterization, stenting and resolution of his cardiogenic
shock and removal of the balloon pump, he had no further issues
with chest pain. He will continue on Aspirin 325 mg PO daily,
Plavix 75 mg PO daily and a high dose statin medication. The
patient had an episode of VT but was hemodynamically stable
during the night of [**10-30**]. He had sudden onset of ventricular
fibrillation and was pulseless, he received ACLS including
intubation, electrical shocks, epinephrine, lidocaine,
magnesium. He was taken emergently to the cath lab, where his
LIMA was found to be occluded. The patient required IABP,
ventricular pacer wire and epinephrine drip. His family decided
to make the patient DNR and he expired on [**10-30**] around 1600.
.
# RHYTHM - The patient presented in sinus rhythm. He was
carefully monitored in the post-intervention period for the
development of arrhythmia. He was monitored via telemtry, his
electrolytes were optimized.
.
# CHRONIC RENAL INSUFFICIENCY - The patient presented with an
unclear baseline, but known chronic renal insufficiency. His
last creatinine in our records was 1.4 and he presented with a
creatinine in the 1.7 range, likely secondary to forward flow
issues. His creatinine stabilized following cardiogenic shock
treatment, with improvement in his cardiac index. We avoided
nephrotoxic medications and renally dosed his medications.
.
# HYPERTENSION - hold amlodipine, valsartan, hydralazine, imdur
for now
.
# GERD - He was continued on Omeprazole at his home dosing.
.

Admission Date:  [**2120-12-4**]       Discharge Date:  [**2120-12-15**]

Date of Birth:   [**2067-2-15**]       Sex:  M

Service:  CT SURGERY

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:   The patient is a 53-year-old
male with a history of coronary artery disease status post
multiple percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasties
with stents.  He was symptom-free for two weeks status post
the last stent.  Since then, he has had progressive angina
and occasional angina at rest.  No history of orthopnea,
paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, or lower extremity edema.
Denies atrial fibrillation or transient ischemic attack.  No
claudication.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:   Noncontributory.

MEDICATIONS:   Aspirin 325 mg once daily, Lopressor 25 mg
twice a day, Protonix 40 mg once daily, Lipitor 20 mg once
daily, Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

ALLERGIES:   No known drug allergies.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:   Cardiac:  Regular rate and rhythm,
Grade I/VI systolic murmur.  Pulmonary:  Clear to
auscultation bilaterally.  Abdomen:  Soft, nontender,
nondistended.  Extremities:  No edema.

HOSPITAL COURSE:   The patient was brought to the operating
room on [**2120-12-5**], where a coronary artery bypass graft x 4
was performed.  Left internal mammary artery went to left
anterior descending, saphenous vein graft to diagonal,
saphenous vein graft to obtuse marginal I, saphenous vein
graft to obtuse marginal III.  The pericardium was left open.
An arterial line and right internal jugular with a Swan-Ganz
catheter were placed.  Two atrial wires as well as two
mediastinal tubes and one pleural tube were placed.  His EBB
equals 98 minutes, XTL equals 66 minutes.

Postoperatively, the patient was transferred to the Intensive
Care Unit, where he was rapidly extubated.  On postoperative
day one, his mediastinal and pleural tubes were removed.  He
was kept in the Intensive Care Unit for aggressive pulmonary
toilet on postoperative day two.  On postoperative day two,
the patient was noted to have tachycardia and diaphoresis
despite albuterol nebulizers and pain control.  He began to
become hypoxemic.  A chest x-ray revealed a consolidation
with pneumonia, for which levofloxacin and vancomycin were
started.  The patient was reintubated and was once again
stable.  A TTE performed at that time revealed right
ventricular hypokinesis and mild mitral regurgitation.  No
pericardial effusion, and the left ventricular ejection
fraction was preserved.

The patient was stable on the ventilator.  He was on a
Neo-Synephrine and propofol drip.  Tube feeds were started
also on postoperative day two.  The patient's hematocrit fell
to 23 on two occasions, for which he received two units of
packed red blood cells each time.  The ventilator began to be
weaned on postoperative day three, and on postoperative day
four, the patient was extubated again.  The Neo-Synephrine
drip was also weaned.

The patient was stable in the Intensive Care Unit, and was
transferred to the floor on [**2120-12-11**], in the evening.
This is now postoperative day seven.  On the floor, he was
slow with ambulation, but eventually improved significantly.
He was tolerating a regular diet, and levofloxacin and
vancomycin were discontinued.  Laboratories were stable, with
a hematocrit of 32.3, white count 5.8, potassium 4.2, BUN 21,
creatinine .7.

CONDITION ON DISCHARGE:   Stable.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:   Lopressor 25 mg twice a day, lasix
20 mg twice a day, potassium chloride 20 mEq twice a day,
Colace 100 mg twice a day, aspirin 325 mg once daily, Plavix
75 mg once daily, Lipitor 20 mg once daily, Protonix 20 mg
once daily, Tylenol and percocet one to two tablets by mouth
every four to six hours as needed.

DISCHARGE STATUS:  Home.

FO[**Last Name (STitle) 996**]P:  With primary care physician in three weeks,
follow up with Dr. [**Last Name (Prefixes) **] in four weeks.

Brief Hospital Course:
As mentioned in the HPI, Mr. [**Known lastname 72438**] was seen in the cardiac
surgery office and was transferred over to [**Hospital1 18**] where he was
admitted. On [**4-24**] he was brought for a cardiac cath which
revealed severe three vessel disease and occluded vein grafts.
Over the next couple days he received medical management and was
the taken to the operating room on [**2182-4-26**]. The patient on
induction had a bradycardic cardiac arrest and had to be
resuscitated by chest compressions and a bolus of epinephrine to
resuscitate him. Before starting the surgery, in view of the
arrest, an intra-aortic balloon pump was placed through the
right femoral artery. After a period of resuscitation, the
patient stabilized and surgery was commenced. He underwent a
redo-sternotomy, coronary artery bypass graft x 4. Please see
operative report for details. In view of the poor cardiac
function, cardiac arrest, and multiple drips, the decision was
made to leave the chest open. Following surgery he was
transferred to the CSRU for invasive monitoring on multiple
inotropes in critical condition. On post-op day one he was taken
back to the operating room where he underwent closure of his
sternotomy. Please see operative report for details. He was then
transferred back to the CSRU for invasive monitoring. He
remained intubated on multiple vasoactive drips and with a
balloon pump. His IABP was weaned successfully and dc'd on POD
#3. He was seen by vascular surgery for a loss of DP/and PT
signals after the IABP was removed, and a heparin gtt was
recommended.  He was taken to the operating room by vascular
surgery on [**4-30**] where he underwent a right femoral thrombectomy
and patch angioplasty. As such, he will require 3 months of
coumadin. He went into afib on [**5-1**] with a drop in BP/SVO2 and
CO, and required cardioversion which was unsuccessful, he was
started on amiodarone. He was seen by infectious diseases for
persistent fever, rising whiwte count and increase in ETT
secretions. Bronchoscopy revealed pneumonia in RUL and LLL,
sputum culture showed gram + cocci and gram negative rods, and
was started on vacomycin and zosyn.He was also found to have a
gram positive bacteremia and rising LFTs. Abdominal ultrasound
was negative. He was extubated on [**5-4**]. Bedside swallow
evaluation showed aspiration and the patient remained NPO. Tube
feeds were started. His creatinine rose but improved with
discontinuation of his lasix gtt. He continued to be followed by
[**Last Name (un) **] at times requiring an insulin drip, his lantus and
sliding scale were increased. He was transferred to the floor on
[**5-9**]. Repeat swallow evaluation on [**5-10**], diet was advanced to
regular with thin liquids. He was seen again by ID on [**5-13**] for
his groin wound, recommendations were to continue Vancomycin for
at least seven days after discharge depending on the state of
his groin.  By [**5-15**] he was ready for discharge to a
rehabilitation facility

monitoring.  In the first twenty four hours she was weaned from

operative day one she was started on lopressor and became

she was monitored in the CVICU.  She no longer required pacing

had sinus pauses and therefore the Amiodarone was discontinued.
Warfarin therapy was initiated for intermittent atrial
fibrillation with rate control. She was ready for discharge to
rehab on post operative day 6.

coumadin), severe decubitus ulcers, reccurrent UTI, who presents
with urosepsis and afib w/RVR.
.
# Sepsis: Resolved on transfer to floor. Pt was afebrile during
her wards course. She was transitioned from vancomycin and zosyn
when culture data available for urine - growing ecoli and
providencia stuartii. Continued on vancomycin for HAP and
changed to ceftriaxone for UTI. Broadly covered given her
history of MRSA. Discontinued bactrim for decubitus ulcers that
was started prior to admission. Do not suspect this is nidus for
her sepsis and concerned for potential antibiotic resistance
with long term abx therapy. Blood culture have been negative to
date. Her femoral line was removed and cultured and no growth to
date as well. R picc line was placed for antibiotic
administration, please discontinue after abx completed. She
appears clinically stable for dc to rehab at this time. Plan to
continue antibiotic coverage until [**2188-11-21**] for planned 8 day
coverage.
.
# Afib: Afib w RVR on admission and noted to be in pAfib during
her stay. Was not admitted on any nodal or antihypertensive
agents, currently on coumadin for CHADS of 5. Was
supratherapeutic on admission. TFTs wnl on admission - not cause
of sinus tach. Hemodynamically stabilized in MICU with volume
resuscitation. She was then started on metoprolol tartrate 25mg
[**Hospital1 **] for rate control on [**11-14**] w good result.
*INR is currently therapeutic (goal 2.0-3.0) off coumadin.
Elevated level likely [**1-15**] to cephalosporin interaction. After
discussion with family/HCP daughter decision was made to
continue anticoagulation for recurrent dvts and afib. Plan to
follow with daily INR levels and restart coumadin when INR<2.0.
.
# Sacral decub infections: Present on admission - this has been
chronic problem for her. Listed initially as possible nidus of
infection, although currently appears to be stable. Wound
consult followed pt and made recommendations during her stay -
plan to continue per PAGE1 included in dc planning papers. Pt
was admitted on bactrim therapy for treatment of decubitus ulcer
however this was held during her stay while being treated w
other antibiotics. Do not believe that patient requires
antibiotic coverage at this time for her ulcers.
.
#. Anemia: pt's baseline is unclear but likely around 28-30. She
was guaiac negative during her stay. Post-MICU Hct was noted to
downtrend from 37 (thought to be hemoconcentrated and
artificially elevated) to 20. Unclear etiology for anemia
however it is possible that guaiac screenings did not detect
slow occult bleed. Pt did not exhibit abd pain that would lead
us to suspect RP bleed. She was transfused 2u pRBCs on [**11-15**] for
anemia and responded appropriately. Hct stable at time of
discharge. Plan to check Hct in 5 days or sooner if restarting
coumadin.
.
# DM: continued on insulin ss (humalog).
.
# Aortic Stenosis: TTE was obtained during her stay showing
worsening aortic stenosis. Pt can be followed as an outpt. Felt
to be euvolemic on evaluation after volume resuscitation in MICU
and 1 day of maintenance fluids on wards. Please discuss w PCP.

.
# Advanced AD: severe nonverbal/babbles at baseline. Never
oriented to person, place, or time. She was noted to be a MS
baseline on transfer to the floor, confirmed with HCP.
.
# Goals of care: discussed with daughter on [**11-17**] via phone (HCP
unable to come into hospital). She wishes to treat all acute
medical issues for her mother including anticoagulation for
recurrent DVTs and coumadin ppx for afib.
.
# Recurrent DVTs: Currently holding anticoagulation given
anemia, therapeutic INR and increased risk for bleeding. Pt had
been on anticoagulation for recurrent DVTs and afib (CHADS 5).
Discussed goals of care w her daughter who would "like
everything done if possible except for CPR and intubation." She
prefers to continue coumadin even with increased bleeding risk.
Plan to restart coumadin when INR<2.0 with goal 2.0-3.0.
.
# Urinary incontinence: Pt had foley placed for volume
monitoring while inpt - plan to dc at rehab and monitor UO. To
avoid delirium, infection (given multiple admissions for
urosepsis) and atonic bladder complications would recommend
straight catheterizing twice daily at rehab.
.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital and brought to the
operating room on [**2108-9-19**] where the patient underwent urgent
coronary artery bypass graft times six.  Left internal mammary
artery to left anterior descending artery and saphenous vein
grafts to posterior descending artery, obtuse marginal 1 and 2,
and diagonal 1 and 2, and Endoscopic harvesting of the long
saphenous vein.  See operative note for full deatils. Overall
the patient tolerated the procedure well and post-operatively
was transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery
and invasive monitoring. Post-operative day one found the
patient extubated, alert and oriented and breathing comfortably.
Initially she had no underlying rhythm and remained DDD paced.
The electrophysiology service was consulted.  Lopressor was
initiated once the patient regained her rhythm and she was
tolerating beta blockers with a rate in the 80's.  The patient
was neurologically intact and hemodynamically stable on no
inotropic or vasopressor support. She was gently diuresed toward
the preoperative weight.  The patient was transferred to the
telemetry floor for further recovery.  Mediastinal chest tubes
were removed and the pleural chest tube stayed in an additional
day due to an air leak.  After the pleural chest tube was on
waterseal for greater than twenty-four hours with a small stable
left pneumothorax, pleural chest tube was pulled. Follow up
chest radiograph showed small stable left pneumothorax. Pacing
wires were discontinued without complication on post-operative
day four. The patient was evaluated by the physical therapy
service for assistance with strength and mobility.  By the time
of discharge on post-operative day six the patient was
ambulating freely, the wound was healing and pain was controlled
with oral analgesics.  The patient was discharged to [**Doctor First Name 391**] [**Hospital **]
Rehab in good condition with appropriate follow up instructions.
